channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Saturday Profile: U.N. Envoy Draws on Her Own Past to Help Abused Women
item.description: Zainab Bangura, as the special envoy for sexual violence in conflict, documents abuses against women — the wars within the wars for power and riches.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Zainab Bangura, the United Nations special envoy for sexual violence in conflict. According to her latest report, 45 armed groups around the world use sexual violence as a weapon.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Plan to Resettle Hong Kongers in Northern Ireland? Surely You Jest
item.description: A proposal discussed by British officials in the early 1980s may have been a joke, but it highlighted concerns in Hong Kong about the impending handover and in Northern Ireland about ongoing sectarian unrest.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The handover ceremony to mark Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.

item.title: Aleppo Fighting Flares Up as Syria Insurgents Attack
item.description: In the worst fighting in the divided Syrian city in months, insurgents unleashed rockets and shell, and civilians came under fire from both sides.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and MAHER SAMAAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Gifts of Eternal Greece
item.description: They are our brothers and our sisters, and we must cherish them as such. We shall miss them terribly if they go.
item.dc:creator: ARMAND MARIE LEROI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Marooned by History in India and Bangladesh
item.description: The two countries finally swap enclaves held over from another era, but the locals are worried.
item.dc:creator: KAI FRIESE

item.title: Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian Teenager in West Bank
item.description: The Israeli military said he and others were throwing stones and rocks, but the Palestinian news media said he was shot trying to scale a wall near a crossing point.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Greece’s Sorry Reckoning
item.description: A lot more is at stake than the only stable currency the nation has had in a history punctuated by bankruptcies.
item.dc:creator: NIKOS KONSTANDARAS

item.title: Shinzo Abe Faces Growing Wrath of Okinawans Over U.S. Base
item.description: The Japanese prime minister’s determination to push ahead with plans to build a new airfield is emerging as one of his first big political challenges.
item.dc:creator: MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: U.S.-China Adventure Film Already Creating Buzz
item.description: “The Great Wall,” a $150 million film directed by Zhang Yimou, is the largest-ever Hollywood-China co-production, which will exempt it from China’s strict import quota on foreign films and entitle its foreign production partners to a larger share of the box-office revenue.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.media:description: At a news conference in Beijing on Thursday, the actress Jing Tian, second from right, and the actor Pedro Pascal, right, take a selfie. From the left, the Hong Kong movie star Andy Lau, the American actor Matt Damon and the Chinese film director Zhang Yimou.

item.title: Alexis Tsipras’s Enemies in Europe See Their Chance in Vote on Greece’s Bailout Terms
item.description: Opponents of Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras are backing a “yes” vote in a referendum on a deal with Greece’s creditors, hoping that outcome will force his ouster.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras has complained about European interference in a referendum on a deal with Greece’s creditors.

item.title: Signs of a Compromise Over Inspections in Iran Nuclear Talks
item.description: An Iranian official signaled a willingness to accept Western demands for inspections of any nuclear-related facility, despite a previous rejection of such actions by the supreme leader.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Supreme Leader Official Website/Handout/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader of Iran, at a government meeting in June. He has said repeatedly that foreigners will not be allowed to visit military sites.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Sudan: 2 Sanctioned by U.S.
item.description: Two commanders leading the opposing sides in the civil war convulsing South Sudan were sanctioned by the Treasury Department on Thursday for fomenting the conflict.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Problem of ‘Religion,’ and Polling, in China
item.description: China’s seemingly high number of atheists may have more to do with the politics of language than a rejection of religious belief.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON
item.media:description: Catholics celebrating Christmas Eve Mass at a church in Beijing.

item.title: Hopeful Start to Greek Debt Negotiations Quickly Soured
item.description: Why Alexis Tsipras took the extreme step of a referendum remains puzzling. But a look at the events reveals missed chances between Greece and its creditors that led him to think a deal was impossible.
item.dc:creator: LANDON THOMAS Jr.
item.media:description: Greek pensioners lined up in front of a bank on Thursday for their limited withdrawals.

item.title: Yemen Expects a Pause in Fighting for Aid Deliveries
item.description: If a pause is agreed to, it will be a victory in efforts to push Saudi Arabia to let up the airstrikes long enough for food and fuel to be delivered.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Germany, Again, Calls on U.S. to Answer Spying Accusations
item.description: The revelations come after previous WikiLeaks revelations suggesting extensive American spying on European allies.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Jihadist From Tunisia Died in Strike in Libya, U.S. Official Says
item.description: Seifallah Ben Hassine, one of Osama bin Laden’s top lieutenants and Tunisia’s most wanted jihadist, was killed in an American airstrike in Libya last month, a senior United States official said.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Liberia Reports New Cases of Ebola
item.description: Three cases have emerged in the country since it was declared free of the virus on May 9, highlighting the continuing threat of viral outbreaks in West Africa.
item.dc:creator: CLAIR MacDOUGALL

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Strike Kills an ISIS Leader
item.description: The United States military said Thursday that a coalition airstrike in Syria had killed a senior Islamic State leader who helped raise money, secure arms and transport fighters for the militant group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Boko Haram Militants Suspected in Attacks at Mosques in Nigeria
item.description: Up to 150 people were gunned down in three locations, according to witnesses, in attacks by gunmen thought to be members of Boko Haram.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
